entries.javadoc:
Represents a unique combination of component types.

Archetypes are the backbone of the ECS storage model. Every entity in a {@link Store} is associated with an Archetype, which determines its memory layout and which systems can process it. Archetypes are immutable; adding or removing components creates a new Archetype instance.

Implements {@link Query} as a shorthand for "any entity containing all components in this archetype."

A contiguous storage block for entities sharing the same {@link Archetype}.

ArchetypeChunks provide high-performance component storage using a Data Oriented Design (SoA - Structure of Arrays). Each component type in the archetype is stored in its own array, allowing systems to iterate over components of a specific type with maximum cache efficiency.

Entities within a chunk are identified by their index. When an entity is removed, the last entity in the chunk is moved to its position to keep the storage tight.

Queues entity and component modifications for deferred execution on the Store thread.

Since {@link Store} is not thread-safe and must be modified from its owner thread, the CommandBuffer provides a way for other threads (or parallel systems) to request changes like adding/removing components or spawning entities.

Commands recorded in the buffer are executed in order when the buffer is consumed. It also implements {@link ComponentAccessor} to allow read-access to the store during command recording.

Base interface for all components within the ECS.

Components are data containers attached to entities within a {@link Store}. They should ideally contain only state, with logic residing in systems. The {@code ECS_TYPE} parameter binds the component to a specific ECS domain.

Unified interface for accessing and modifying components and entities within a store.

Implemented by both {@link Store} (direct access) and {@link CommandBuffer} (deferred access). This allows systems to be written against a common API regardless of whether they are running on the store thread or in parallel.

Central registry for all component types, systems, and resource types within an ECS domain.

The ComponentRegistry manages the static schema of an ECS domain. It handles the registration of {@link ComponentType}s, {@link SystemType}s, and {@link ResourceType}s. It also maintains the collection of active {@link Store}s associated with this registry.

When components or systems are registered or unregistered, the registry rebuilds its internal {@link Data} view, which is then propagated to all associated stores. This ensures that stores always have an up-to-date view of the ECS topology.

An immutable snapshot of the {@link ComponentRegistry} schema.

The Data class provides a thread-safe, read-only view of all registered component types, system types, and codecs. It is updated whenever the registry state changes and propagated to all associated stores to ensure consistency during multi-threaded access.

A proxy implementation of {@link IComponentRegistry} that tracks registrations and allows for bulk unregistration.

This is typically used by plugins to register their own component, resource, and system types. When the plugin is disabled or unloaded, the proxy can automatically unregister all its contributions from the main {@link ComponentRegistry}.

A unique identifier and metadata for a specific type of component.

Each ComponentType is registered within a {@link ComponentRegistry} and assigned a unique index. This index is used to look up component data within an {@link ArchetypeChunk}.

ComponentTypes also implement {@link Query}, allowing them to be used as a filter for entities that possess a component of this type.

Base class for defining execution order constraints between ECS systems.

Dependencies allow systems to specify that they must run before or after other systems, specific system types, or entire system groups. This is used by the {@link DependencyGraph} to build a valid execution order.

A directed graph used to resolve and sort ECS systems based on their dependencies.

The graph takes a set of systems and their declared {@link Dependency} constraints, resolves them into edges, and performs a topological sort to find a stable execution order for the ECS tick.
Identifier for an ECS event type that is dispatched on a per-entity basis.
Base class for ECS system types that handle specific {@link EcsEvent} types.
Identifier for an ECS event type that is dispatched globally within a store.

A mutable container for an entity's components, used for transport and initialization.

Holders act as templates or "detached" entities. They are used to group a set of components together before they are added to a {@link Store}, or to hold components after an entity has been removed. Unlike {@link Ref}, a Holder contains the actual component data and can be modified independently of any Store.

Holders are thread-safe and use an internal lock to manage concurrent access to their component collection.

Interface definition for an ECS component and system registry.

This interface defines the contract for registering all core ECS elements, including components, resources, systems, and event types. It's primarily implemented by {@link ComponentRegistry}.

Interface for loading, saving, and removing ECS resource data.

Resources are domain-wide data (like world settings or shared systems data) that need to be persisted or loaded asynchronously. implementations of this interface handle the actual I/O operations.
Data record for metrics related to an {@link ArchetypeChunk}.
Data record for metrics related to an ECS system.

Marker component indicating an entity should not be serialized to disk.

Entities with this component are excluded from save operations. Useful for transient entities like visual effects or temporary debug markers.

Marker component that excludes entities from {@link com.hypixel.hytale.component.system.tick.TickingSystem} processing.

When an entity has this component, it will be filtered out from all ticking systems unless they explicitly opt-in via {@code isExplicitQuery()}.
A composite query that matches if all its sub-queries match.
A query that matches all entities unconditionally.

A query that matches entities having exactly the specified {@link Archetype}.

Unlike a standard archetype query which matches if an entity has at least the requested components, this query requires an exact identity match on the archetype.
A query that inverts the result of its sub-query.
A composite query that matches if any of its sub-queries match.

Interface for filtering entities based on their {@link Archetype}.

Queries are used by systems and stores to efficiently find or filter entities that possess a specific combination of components. They can be composed using boolean logic (AND, OR, NOT).

A query that distinguishes between components being read and components being modified.

Used by the parallel scheduler to determine which systems can run concurrently. Systems with overlapping "write" archetypes or "read/write" conflicts must be serialized.

Standard implementation of a {@link ReadWriteArchetypeQuery}.

Specifies two archetypes: one containing components that will only be read, and another containing components that may be modified.

A stable, type-safe handle to an entity within a {@link Store}.

Unlike raw entity indices which can be reused after an entity is destroyed, a {@code Ref} is invalidated when its entity is removed from the store. This provides a safe way to store references to entities across ticks or in components without risking "zombie" entity access.

References are specific to a single Store instance and maintain the entity's current index within that store.

Base interface for domain-wide data containers within an ECS Store.

Unlike components, which are attached to specific entities, resources are singleton-like objects that provide global state or shared data for all systems within a {@link Store}.

A unique identifier and metadata for a specific type of resource.

Each ResourceType is registered within a {@link ComponentRegistry} and assigned a unique index. This index is used to look up resource data within a {@link Store}.

A resource that stores spatial indexing data for an ECS domain.

The SpatialResource holds a {@link SpatialStructure} that is periodically updated by a {@link SpatialSystem} to allow systems to perform fast point, radius, or volume searches for entities.

Interface for spatial acceleration structures used to index entities.

Implementations (such as {@link KDTree}) provide methods for querying entities based on their 3D coordinates, including sphere, box, and cylinder collection.

An ECS system that maintains a spatial acceleration structure for entities.

This system iterates over all entities in the store, extracts their positions via {@link #getPosition}, and rebuilds a {@link SpatialStructure} (like a KD-Tree) to enable efficient proximity queries (e.g., finding nearby entities).

The primary container for an ECS domain, managing entities, components, and systems.

A Store maintains the lifecycle of entities within a specific domain (such as {@code EntityStore} or {@code ChunkStore}). It uses an archetype-based storage model where entities with the same set of components are grouped into {@link ArchetypeChunk}s. This layout optimizes memory locality and cache efficiency during system iteration.

Key responsibilities include:

  • Entity creation and removal via {@link Holder} containers
  • System registration and execution order management
  • Resource storage and persistence
  • Parallelized ticking of matching entities via {@code Query}

Stores are strictly thread-bound; all modifications must occur on the thread that owns the Store. For cross-thread synchronization, use the {@link CommandBuffer}.

Base class for systems that react to the creation or destruction of ArchetypeChunks.

Each time a new combination of components is created, the Store creates a corresponding {@link ArchetypeChunk}. This system type allows for performing initialization logic specific to those storage blocks.

Abstract base class for {@link EcsEvent}s that can be cancelled.

Provides standard cancellation state management. Event listeners can check {@link #isCancelled()} to short-circuit processing.
Base class for all events dispatched within the ECS framework.
Base class for listeners that process {@link EcsEvent}s within an ECS domain.

Reactive system that processes entity data at the boundaries of Store addition/removal.

Unlike {@link RefSystem} which operates on entities already in the store, HolderSystem receives callbacks with {@link Holder} containers before the entity is assigned an index (on add) and after it has been removed (on remove).

Use this for validation, resource acquisition, or modifying the holder's component set before entity creation.

Contract for events that support cancellation.

Event handlers can check {@link #isCancelled()} to determine if the event has been aborted by a previous listener and skip further processing.

Base interface for all systems within the ECS.

Systems contain the logic that operates on components. An ISystem is registered with a {@link ComponentRegistry} and can belong to a {@link SystemGroup} to control its execution order relative to other systems.

Execution order is determined by a {@link DependencyGraph} based on explicit dependencies and group assignments.

Interface for systems that export runtime metrics for monitoring and debugging.

Systems implementing this can provide custom performance data or statistics that are collected and exposed via the metrics registry. This is used for profiling, observability, and diagnostics.

Interface for ECS systems that operate on a filtered subset of entities.

Systems implementing this interface define a {@link Query} that determines which entities (via their archetypes) the system is interested in.

Base class for reactive systems that respond to specific component modifications.

Unlike {@link RefSystem}, which reacts to entity lifecycle events, this class triggers when a specific type of component is added to, removed from, or updated on an entity. This is useful for synchronizing external state with specific component data.

Base class for reactive ECS systems that respond to entity lifecycle events.

Subclasses define a query and receive callbacks when matching entities are added to or removed from the store. Use this for index maintenance, resource allocation, or any logic triggered by component presence changes.

Base class for systems that respond to their own addition or removal from a Store.

Use this for systems that need to initialize store-specific state, resources, or lookup indices when they are attached to an ECS domain instance.

Abstract base class for systems that register components and resources.

A System provides helper methods for registering new {@link ComponentType}s and {@link ResourceType}s. These registrations are collected and processed by the {@link ComponentRegistry} when the system is added.

A specialized {@link TickingSystem} that iterates over entities in batches using {@link ArchetypeChunk}s.

This system optimizes iteration by processing entities chunk-by-chunk. It implements {@link QuerySystem} to define which entities it matches.

By default, this system automatically excludes entities with "NonTicking" components unless {@link #isExplicitQuery()} returns true. @see EntityTickingSystem

A variation of {@link EntityTickingSystem} that runs at a fixed interval rather than every frame.

This is useful for expensive or non-critical logic that doesn't need 60Hz updates, such as AI decision making, pathfinding recalculations, or periodic status regeneration.

The system maintains an internal timer (stored as a {@link Resource}) to track accumulated time between executions.

The standard base class for systems that process individual entities every frame.

Subclasses implement {@link #tick(float, int, ArchetypeChunk, Store, CommandBuffer)} to define logic for a single entity. The system handles the iteration over all matching chunks and entities.

Parallelism

This system supports parallel execution via the job system. Override {@link #isParallel} (or {@link #useParallel}) to enable this. When running in parallel, the system uses {@link SystemTaskData} to distribute work across worker threads.

Note: Thread safety is critical when parallelism is enabled. Use the provided {@link CommandBuffer} for all structural modifications (adding/removing entities/components). @see ArchetypeTickingSystem

Data container for parallel tick tasks.

This class holds the context required to tick a single entity (or range of entities) on a worker thread. It is pooled and reused by the {@link ParallelTask} system to minimize allocation overhead.

Marker interface for systems that should continue executing even when the game loop is paused.

Normally, a {@link Store} may skip ticking most systems if the game state is paused. Systems implementing this interface bypass that check. Examples include UI input handling, network keep-alives, or menu animations.

Base abstract implementation for systems that run every tick.

Extends the registration capabilities of {@link System} with the {@link TickableSystem} interface. Most game logic systems should extend {@link EntityTickingSystem} instead of this class directly, unless they do not operate on specific entities (e.g., a global time manager). @see EntityTickingSystem

Groups related systems for ordered execution within an ECS tick phase.

Systems assigned to the same group run together in dependency order. Groups themselves are ordered by index within the registry. Used to ensure operations like network synchronization happen at consistent points in the tick.

Metadata and identifier for a specific type or class of ECS system.

SystemTypes are used to categorize systems within a {@link ComponentRegistry}. They allow for retrieving systems by their base class or interface, and are used to identify built-in system categories like {@code TickingSystem} or {@code RefSystem}.

A sub-task of {@link ParallelTask} that processes a specific range of indices.

This task further divides its range into smaller {@link SubTask}s based on the available parallelism of the system.

A task that can be executed in parallel using the ForkJoin framework.

This task splits a larger workload into multiple {@link ParallelRangeTask}s that can be processed concurrently on different threads.

Primary implementation of the Hytale event bus system.

The EventBus manages the registration and dispatching of both synchronous and asynchronous events. It uses {@link EventBusRegistry} instances to categorize listeners by event type and optional lookup keys, allowing for highly efficient event targeting (e.g., world-specific or entity-specific events).

Interface for the central event distribution system.

Provides methods for dispatching synchronous and asynchronous events, with support for targeted dispatching based on event keys.

Base interface for all network packets in the Hytale protocol.

Each packet defines its unique ID, serialization logic to a {@link ByteBuf}, and its expected size in bytes. Packets are registered within the {@link PacketRegistry} to be correctly encoded and decoded by the networking layer.

Central registry for all network packets in the Hytale protocol.

This registry maps packet IDs to their respective classes and provides the necessary logic for packet serialization, deserialization, and structural validation. It contains a massive static mapping of the Hytale protocol, including authentication, world synchronization, asset transfer, entity updates, and UI interactions.

The base class for all game entities in the Hytale server.

Entity represents any dynamic object in the world, from players and creatures to projectiles and dropped items. It integrates with the ECS via the Entity Wrapper Pattern: the Entity itself is a {@link Component} that holds a {@link Ref} to the underlying ECS entity.

Entity Lifecycle

  1. Construction: Create the entity instance via subclass constructor
  2. Loading: Call {@link #loadIntoWorld(World)} to assign it to a world
  3. Spawning: Add to {@link EntityStore} via {@link EntityStore#addEntity}
  4. Active: Entity processes via ECS systems each tick
  5. Removal: Call {@link #remove()} to despawn from the world

Key Concepts for Modders

  • ECS Integration: Always access/modify entity state through the {@link Ref} and {@link ComponentAccessor}, never via direct field mutation during ticks
  • Thread Safety: Entity operations must occur on the world's ticking thread
  • Network ID: Each entity gets a unique network identifier for client synchronization
  • Transform: Position and rotation are stored in {@link TransformComponent}
@see LivingEntity @see com.hypixel.hytale.server.core.entity.entities.Player @see com.hypixel.hytale.server.core.modules.entity.EntityModule

The base class for all living entities, adding health, inventory, and advanced movement.

LivingEntity extends {@link Entity} with features common to creatures, players, and NPCs:

  • Inventory System: Access via {@link #getInventory()}, includes armor and equipment
  • Stat Modifiers: Managed by {@link StatModifiersManager} for buffs/debuffs
  • Fall Damage: Tracks {@link #currentFallDistance} for physics calculations
  • Equipment: Network synchronization for visual changes
  • Breathing: Fluid detection via {@link #canBreathe}

For Plugin Developers

When creating custom creature types, extend this class and override:

  • {@link #createDefaultInventory()} - Define starting equipment
  • {@link #canDecreaseItemStackDurability} - Control item wear
@see com.hypixel.hytale.server.core.entity.entities.Player @see com.hypixel.hytale.server.core.inventory.Inventory @see StatModifiersManager

The main entry point and singleton controller for the Hytale server.

The HytaleServer class orchestrates the entire server lifecycle, including configuration loading, plugin management, universe/world initialization, and the networking layer. It provides access to central managers like {@link PluginManager}, {@link EventBus}, and {@link CommandManager}.

In singleplayer mode, it also communicates startup progress back to the client through specialized log signals.

Base class for all events related to a {@link PluginBase}.

These events are dispatched through the global event bus and allow other systems to react to changes in a plugin's state or lifecycle.

Event dispatched when a {@link PluginBase} has finished its {@code setup()} phase.

This event signals that the plugin has completed its static registrations (ECS, commands, events) and is ready for the start phase.

The primary entry point for all Java-based Hytale plugins.

JavaPlugin extends the core {@link PluginBase} with features specific to third-party extensions. It manages the plugin's isolated {@link PluginClassLoader}, which provides class isolation while allowing access to the Hytale Server API.

Additionally, JavaPlugin handles the automatic registration of embedded asset packs if declared in the plugin's manifest. Subclasses should implement logic by overriding:

  • {@link #setup()}: For static registrations (ECS components, systems, event listeners).
  • {@link #start()}: For logic that requires all plugins to have completed their setup phase.
  • {@link #shutdown()}: For gracefully releasing resources and stopping background tasks.
Returns the path to the physical JAR file for this plugin.
Returns the isolated class loader for this plugin.

Initialization context specifically for {@link JavaPlugin} instances.

Extends {@link PluginInit} with Java-specific data such as the plugin's JAR file path and the specialized {@link PluginClassLoader}.
Returns the path to the plugin's JAR file.
Returns the class loader used for this Java plugin.

Thrown when a plugin cannot be loaded due to a missing or incompatible dependency.

This includes cases where:

  • A required dependency is not present
  • The dependency's version doesn't satisfy the required {@link com.hypixel.hytale.common.semver.SemverRange}
  • The server version is incompatible with the plugin

The fundamental base class for all server modules and plugins in the Hytale ecosystem.

PluginBase provides the core infrastructure and registry access required for any architectural component. It acts as a central hub for:

  • Registry Management: Access to ECS domains (EntityStore, ChunkStore), event registries, command registries, and asset registries.
  • Lifecycle Handling: Orchestrates the transition through lifecycle states (SETUP -> START -> ENABLED) and provides hooks for initialization and shutdown.
  • Configuration: Manages persistent configuration files associated with the module.
  • Metrics and Logging: Provides a standardized logging context and metrics reporting via the {@link MetricsRegistry}.

From an architectural perspective, every significant logic container in the server (whether a built-in "Module" or a third-party "Plugin") extends this class to participate in the server's lifecycle and gain access to its core systems.

Asynchronously loads all declared configurations.

@return A future that completes when all configs are loaded.

Returns the client feature registry.

Allows plugins to enable or disable specific client-side features (like UI elements, debug rendering, or input handling) for players.

Returns the command registry for this plugin.

Used to register custom chat commands and their handlers.

Returns the event registry for this plugin.

Used to register listeners for server events (e.g., player join, block break).

Returns the block state registry.

Provides access to block state definitions and metadata, useful for querying block properties or modifying block behavior.

Returns the entity registry.

Used for looking up entity types and their associated metadata.

Returns the registry proxy for the {@link EntityStore}.

Used to register custom component types and systems for dynamic entities.

Returns the registry proxy for the {@link ChunkStore}.

Used to register custom component types for chunks, commonly used for attaching data to blocks (the Block Component Pattern).

Returns the asset registry for this plugin.

Used to register custom assets (models, textures, sounds) programmatically. Assets registered here are properly tracked and unloaded on plugin shutdown.

Returns a registry for codec-based data maps.

This allows plugins to register custom data structures that can be serialized/deserialized using the provided codec. @param mapCodec The codec defining the data structure.

Returns a registry for map-key based data.

@param mapCodec The map key codec.

Returns the base permission node for this plugin.

Typically formatted as {@code group.pluginName}.

Checks if the plugin is currently disabled.

@return true if the plugin state is NONE, DISABLED, or SHUTDOWN.
Checks if the plugin is currently enabled and operational.

Lifecycle hook called during the setup phase.

This method is called early in the plugin lifecycle, before all core systems are fully initialized. Use this for basic initialization tasks such as:

  • Registering event listeners
  • Registering commands
  • Setting up configuration

Warning: Do NOT register ECS components or systems in this method. When plugins are loaded via the {@code --mods} startup argument (as opposed to the mods folder), the initialization order differs and some core component types may not be available yet. For example, {@code Player.getComponentType()} may return {@code null} during this phase, causing {@code NullPointerException} when registering systems that depend on player components.

For ECS component and system registration, use {@link #start()} instead, which is called after all core systems are guaranteed to be initialized. @see #start()

Lifecycle hook called when the plugin is being disabled or the server is shutting down.

Manual cleanup of resources (threads, database connections) should be handled here. Note that most registry entries are automatically cleaned up.

Returns the type of this plugin.

@return {@link PluginType#PLUGIN} for third-party plugins, or other internal types for server modules.

Specialized class loader providing isolation between plugins while allowing controlled sharing.

Each {@link JavaPlugin} receives its own PluginClassLoader, which:

  • Loads classes from the server's core API first (e.g., ECS, events)
  • Loads classes from the plugin's own JAR
  • Uses the {@link PluginManager.PluginBridgeClassLoader} to access declared dependencies

This loader distinguishes between "builtin" plugins (bundled with the server) and "third-party" plugins (external JARs) via the {@code inServerClassPath} flag, which affects error reporting and classloader naming.

Data holder for plugin initialization parameters.

Contains the plugin's manifest and its dedicated data directory.
Returns the manifest containing metadata about the plugin.
Returns the path to the directory where the plugin should store its data.

Manages the registration and notification of {@link PluginListPage}s.

This manager provides a registry for UI pages that display lists of plugins to the client. It handles the synchronization of plugin state changes to all active pages, ensuring the client-side view remains up-to-date as plugins are enabled, disabled, or reloaded.
Singleton instance of the manager.

ECS component that stores session-specific settings for the plugin list UI.

This component is attached to player entities in the {@link EntityStore} to control how plugins are displayed to them in the UI.

The central orchestrator for Hytale's plugin and module ecosystem.

The PluginManager is a singleton responsible for the entire lifecycle of both internal server modules and third-party plugins. Its primary responsibilities include:

  • Discovery: Scanning the classpath and the various plugin directories ({@code builtin}, {@code mods}) for plugin manifest files.
  • Dependency Resolution: Analyzing plugin dependencies and determining a valid load order, handling potential errors like {@link MissingPluginDependencyException}.
  • Lifecycle Management: Transitioning all registered plugins through their lifecycle states (SCAN -> SETUP -> START -> ENABLED) and managing the asynchronous cleanup during shutdown.
  • Class Isolation: Managing the {@link PluginClassLoader} hierarchy to ensure plugins operate in isolation while maintaining shared access to the Server core API and shared libraries.

This manager is a critical component of the server's boot process, ensuring that all game logic systems (implemented as plugins or modules) are correctly initialized before the universe and worlds are loaded.

Scans for plugins and prepares them for initialization.

This method discovers plugins in the core classpath, the {@code builtin} directory, and the {@code mods} directory. It resolves the load order based on dependency declarations and prepares the plugins for the setup phase.
Returns an unmodifiable list of all currently loaded plugins.

Handles the registration of custom assets for a specific plugin or module.

AssetRegistry acts as a proxy to the global asset system, ensuring that any assets registered by a plugin are tracked and can be properly cleaned up when the plugin is disabled or the server shuts down.

Base interface for all architectural registries in the Hytale server.

Registries that implement this interface are expected to handle their own cleanup logic during the {@link #shutdown()} phase.

Component that stores the raw block data and maps for a world chunk.

BlockChunk is responsible for the performance-critical storage of block IDs, heightmaps, and tintmaps within a {@link WorldChunk}. It divides the vertical column into multiple {@link BlockSection}s for efficient network transmission and memory management.

It also manages the chunk's {@link EnvironmentChunk}, which stores biome-related or environmental data used for rendering and world logic.

Represents a logical vertical column of world data, acting as a component of {@link ChunkStore}.

A WorldChunk is a primary container for world-related data within a 32x32 area. It coordinates several sub-chunks:

  • {@link BlockChunk} - stores raw block IDs and metadata.
  • {@link BlockComponentChunk} - manages block-specific entities (Tile Entities).
  • {@link EntityChunk} - tracks entities currently located within the chunk.

WorldChunks also manage their own lifecycle flags (ticking, generated, etc.) and provide the primary API for block modifications and light updates.

The ECS store for world chunks, managing their loading, generation, and persistence.

The ChunkStore treats each world chunk as an ECS entity. This domain-specific ECS handles static world data, block components (Tile Entities), and chunk-wide logic. Chunks are loaded asynchronously from disk or generated on-the-fly via the registered {@link IWorldGen}.

Entities in the ChunkStore are indexed by their chunk coordinate (long), and the store manages the complex lifecycle of chunk statesfrom requested to loaded, ticking, or marked for unload.
Tracks the loading or generation state of a specific chunk.

System responsible for initializing the chunk loader and saver when a ChunkStore
is added to an ECS domain.
System for querying packet data for future chunk loads.
System for querying packet data for currently loading chunks.
System for querying packet data for chunks being unloaded.

The primary ECS store for dynamic game entities (players, mobs, projectiles, etc.).

Each World instance owns one EntityStore. Entities are identified by UUID and network ID, with reactive systems maintaining lookup indices for both. The static REGISTRY holds all registered component types and systems for this ECS domain.

Contains two built-in reactive systems:

  • {@link UUIDSystem} - maintains the UUID-to-entity index
  • {@link NetworkIdSystem} - assigns and tracks client-visible network IDs
Assigns and tracks unique network IDs for entities visible to clients.
Maintains the UUID-to-entity lookup index for the EntityStore.

Interface for asynchronously loading chunk data from persistent storage.

The loader is responsible for reading chunk data and converting it into a {@link Holder} that can be integrated into the {@link ChunkStore}.

The primary container for a game world, running on its own dedicated thread.

A World is a heavy object that extends {@link TickingThread}. It manages its own {@link EntityStore} for dynamic entities and {@link ChunkStore} for static world data and blocks. All logic within a world, including ECS ticking, physics, and event dispatching, occurs on the World's dedicated thread.

Worlds are identified by a unique name and manage the lifecycle of players and chunks within their boundaries. Use {@link #execute(Runnable)} to safely schedule tasks to run on the World thread from other threads.

Persistent configuration settings for a specific game world.

This class manages all world-specific settings including the seed, world generator, chunk storage providers, game rules (PvP, fall damage), and environmental effects. It is serialized to and from JSON/BSON using the {@link BuilderCodec} defined in {@link #CODEC}.

Interface for generating procedural world content.

The world generator is responsible for creating {@link GeneratedChunk}s when they are not found in persistent storage. It operates asynchronously and is triggered by the {@link ChunkStore}.
